hints_html:
Approach this question as a left hand side, right hand side proof problem. We start with the definition of mean and want to get to \(\displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{a}(1-F(x))\,dx\). Starting from \(\displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{a}xp(x)\,dx\), what integration techniques can we use to get a start on it?

Try integration by parts on the mean.

What does \(F(a)\) equal?

If you get stuck, try simplifying the other side of the equality to help.

hints_raw:
Approach this question as a left hand side, right hand side proof problem. We start with the definition of mean and want to get to <math> \displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{a}(1-F(x))\,dx</math>. Starting from <math> \displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{a}xp(x)\,dx</math>, what integration techniques can we use to get a start on it?
Try integration by parts on the mean.
What does <math> F(a) </math> equal?
If you get stuck, try simplifying the other side of the equality to help.
question: 3 (a)
sols_html:
Notice that \(\displaystyle F(x)\) is an antiderivative of \(\displaystyle p(x)\). If we use integration by parts, we let \(\displaystyle u = x\) and \(\displaystyle dv = p(x)dx\) so that \(\displaystyle du = dx\) and \(\displaystyle v = F(x)\) so that

\[\begin{aligned} \overline{x} &= \int_{0}^{a}xp(x)\,dx \\ &= xF(x)\big|_{0}^{a} - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)\,dx \\ &= aF(a) - (0)F(0) - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)\,dx \end{aligned}\]

Now, since the probability distribution is only defined on [0,a] then the cumulative probability satisfies F(0)=0 since nothing can happen before 0 and F(a)=1 since by x=a, there is a 100% chance that our event happened. Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} \overline{x}&= a - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)\,dx \\ &= \int_{0}^{a}1 - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)\,dx \\ &= \int_{0}^{a}(1 - F(x))\,dx \end{aligned}\]

If we missed the second last step, we could have instead simplified the other equation to see that \(\displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{a}(1-F(x))\,dx = a - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)\) and thus the two sides are equal. Either way this completes the proof.
sols_latex:
Notice that $\displaystyle F(x)$ is an antiderivative of
$\displaystyle p(x)$. If we use integration by parts, we let
$\displaystyle u = x$ and $\displaystyle dv = p(x)dx$ so that
$\displaystyle du = dx$ and $\displaystyle v = F(x)$ so that

\begin{align*}
\overline{x} &= \int_{0}^{a}xp(x)\,dx \\
&= xF(x)\big|_{0}^{a} - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)\,dx \\
&= aF(a) - (0)F(0) - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)\,dx 
\end{align*}

Now, since the probability distribution is only defined on {[}0,a{]}
then the cumulative probability satisfies \emph{F(0)=0} since nothing
can happen before 0 and \emph{F(a)=1} since by \emph{x=a}, there is a
100\% chance that our event happened. Therefore,

\begin{align*}
\overline{x}&= a - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_{0}^{a}1 - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_{0}^{a}(1 - F(x))\,dx 
\end{align*}

If we missed the second last step, we could have instead simplified the
other equation to see that
$\displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{a}(1-F(x))\,dx = a - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)$
and thus the two sides are equal. Either way this completes the proof.
sols_raw:
Notice that <math> \displaystyle F(x)</math> is an antiderivative of <math> \displaystyle p(x)</math>. If we use integration by parts, we let <math> \displaystyle u = x</math> and <math> \displaystyle dv = p(x)dx </math> so that <math> \displaystyle du = dx</math> and <math> \displaystyle v = F(x)</math> so that

:<math> 
\begin{align}
\overline{x} &= \int_{0}^{a}xp(x)\,dx \\
&= xF(x)\big|_{0}^{a} - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)\,dx \\
&= aF(a) - (0)F(0) - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)\,dx \\
\end{align}.
</math>

Now, since the probability distribution is only defined on [0,a] then the cumulative probability satisfies ''F(0)=0'' since nothing can happen before 0 and ''F(a)=1'' since by ''x=a'', there is a 100% chance that our event happened.  Therefore,

:<math>
\begin{align}
\overline{x}&= a - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_{0}^{a}1 - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_{0}^{a}(1 - F(x))\,dx \\
\end{align}
</math>

If we missed the second last step, we could have instead simplified the other equation to see that <math> \displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{a}(1-F(x))\,dx = a - \int_{0}^{a}F(x)</math> and thus the two sides are equal. Either way this completes the proof.
statement_html:
Continuous Probability.

Let \(\displaystyle X \geq 0\) be a random variable on the interval \(\displaystyle [0,a]\) with probability density function \(\displaystyle p(x)\). The mean of X is given by \(\displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{a}xp(x)\,dx\). Show that \(\displaystyle \overline{x}\) can also be computed as \(\displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{a}(1-F(x))\,dx\), where \(\displaystyle F(x)\) is the cumulative distribution function (cdf) of X.
statement_latex:
\textbf{Continuous Probability.}

Let $\displaystyle X \geq 0$ be a random variable on the interval
$\displaystyle [0,a]$ with probability density function
$\displaystyle p(x)$. The mean of \emph{X} is given by
$\displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{a}xp(x)\,dx$. Show that
$\displaystyle \overline{x}$ can also be computed as
$\displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{a}(1-F(x))\,dx$, where
$\displaystyle F(x)$ is the cumulative distribution function (cdf) of
\emph{X}.
statement_raw:
'''Continuous Probability.''' 

Let <math> \displaystyle X \geq 0 </math> be a random variable on the interval <math> \displaystyle  [0,a] </math> with probability density function <math> \displaystyle  p(x) </math>. The mean of ''X'' is given by <math> \displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{a}xp(x)\,dx</math>. Show that <math> \displaystyle \overline{x}</math> can also be computed as <math> \displaystyle \overline{x} = \int_{0}^{a}(1-F(x))\,dx</math>, where <math> \displaystyle F(x)</math> is the cumulative distribution function (cdf) of ''X''.
